Draws hope for this year's Christmas celebration
Aftenbladet's drawing competition has been a tradition for over 50 years. In Stokka kindergarten, the children work on their interpretation of "hope".
04 Nov 2019, 19:03 by Christine Andersen Johnsen
Halloween is over, and it's already time to start the many Christmas preparations.
For Stokka kindergarten, Aftenbladet's drawing competition is one of them.

Ready for this year's big Christmas drawing competition: Draw hope!

Magnus (5) is one of the children at Stokka kindergarten who has started drawing for the Aftenbladet drawing competition. He says that he has been thinking about what he likes about Christmas Eve when he has drawn.
- I have drawn Santa who flies with his reindeer to Santa's house. I have also drawn myself, my brother and my friend with winter hats waiting for the Santa, he says. Next to him and his brother, he has drawn a snowman.


Magnus (5) is working on a nice Christmas drawing with everything he hopes for this year's Christmas. Both sun and snow - and not least Santa Claus.ğŸ“· Fredrik Refvem

Last year was the theme of Christmas night, but this year Aftenbladet invites to draw "Hope". Aftenbladet writes that â€œHope can be so much; Some may hope for certain Christmas presents or merry Christmas parties - others may associate hope with the climate match or Christmas stories. There are many opportunities Â».
In Stokka kindergarten they have already started discussing this year's theme for the competition.
Hope Santa Claus is coming
Together with the preschool children, the kindergarten has talked about "hope", in the form of wishes for Christmas and Christmas, and what the children hope to happen or what they want.

Merry Christmas for more than 120 years

Charlotte (4) has drawn a Santa Claus because she hopes Santa Claus will come home to them on Christmas Eve.
- I hope he will come home to us and celebrate Christmas with me, mom and dad, she says. If he comes, she hopes Santa will bring candy with him.


Charlotte (i.e.) has drawn a Santa Claus because she hopes the Santa will visit them on Christmas Eve.ğŸ“· Fredrik Refvem

Ariana (4) is also working on a drawing for the competition. She says she didn't think about what she wanted or hoped for Christmas, because she doesn't quite know it yet. That's why she draws it associates with Christmas and Christmas Eve.
- I drew a Christmas tree and Santa, because that's what Christmas is, she says.
- We'll win!
Comrade Truls (4) also sits at the drawing board, but says he has not drawn anything with the Christmas theme yet.
Truls still has one hope for the Christmas season and the drawing competition:
- We'll win!


Truls and Ariana have so far managed to start enjoying Christmas yet, but they hope they will win the drawing competition.ğŸ“· Fredrik Refvem

Years of tradition
From 1970 there has been a drawing competition with Christmas as a theme every single year - and every year thousands of drawings are submitted. The record is well over 20,000 drawings, in recent years Aftenbladet has received about 15,000 works.
Aftenbladet divides the drawings in the drawing competition into four groups:
1. Child of preschool age, 1st and 2nd grade.
2. Pupils in 3rd, 4th and 5th grade.
3. Pupils in 6th and 7th grade as well as secondary school.
4. Group worker (Group is from and including three people).
In recent years, the competition has had fewer contributions from kindergartens and preschool children. That is why Aftenbladet especially encourages this group to settle down with drawing and painting cases this year.
Deadline
If your kindergarten, school or child wants to participate in the competition, drawings can be delivered by November 20.
